section.title: Velocity
section.p: Motion is frequently modeled using calculus. A building block for this application is the concept of average velocity. Average velocity is defined to be net displacement divided by elapsed time. More precisely,

statement.p: If p is a position function for something moving along a numbered line, then we define the average velocity over the time interval \cinterval{t_0}{t_1} to be: \frac{\fe{p}{t_1}-\fe{p}{t_0}}{t_1-t_0}\text{.}

introduction.p: According to simplified Newtonian physics, if an object is dropped from an elevationIf you encounter an unfamiliar unit of measure while reading this lab manual, see . of 200 meters () and allowed to free fall to the ground, then the elevation of the object is given by the position function \fe{p}{t}=200\,\text{m}-\left(4.9\,\sfrac{\text{m}}{\text{s}^2}\right)t^2 where t is the amount of time that has passed since the object was dropped. (The 200 in the formula represents the elevation from which the object was dropped, and the 4.9 represents one half of the acceleration due to gravity near the surface of Earth.)

remark.title: Units in formulas
remark.p: Thus far we have used a formula where every number that appears in the formula comes with its real world unit (\fe{p}{t}=200\,\text{m}-\left(4.9\,\sfrac{\text{m}}{\text{s}^2}\right)t^2). A formula like this allows you to calculate \fe{p}{5\,\text{s}} or \fe{p}{5\,\text{min}} as you please, as long as you track the units and reduce ratios appropriately.

However, all those units in the original formula might distract you from new calculus topics. We could just write \fe{p}{t}=200-4.9t^2, but if we do so, we have to specify that t is in seconds and \fe{p}{t} is in meters. With this formula, we can calculate something like \fe{p}{5}, but we need to recognize that in context, the 5 means that 5 seconds have passed. And when we arrive at the result, \fe{p}{5}=77.5, we need to realize that the position is 77.5 meters.

For the remainder of this lab manual, formulas will be written in this second way, without explicit units. Each variable will be specified with what unit it is intended to be measured in.
